Dialogue.Stage Direction: Southern England, early 13th century. In a nobleman's hall a feast it taking place. A small jester entertains while music is provided on a lute. Suddenly a sullen man wearing a crown slams his goblet down on the top table.
The lute player stops, stands and bows.

Dialogue.Line: This is a poor welcome, my lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone say Hi! to  Frank Windsor.

Dialogue.Line: Hear us. We have come to ask but a pittance. Three marks per knight's fee. You obstruct the Crusade, my lord, with your parsimony.
But your Majesty already has my whole fortune willingly given but six month's since. There is no more. My coffers are empty.
Your words are more generous than your purse, Lord Ranulf. If you speak truth, if we have your whole fortune, you insult us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The King's Champion, a burly chap with lots of red hair, gets up and throws a gauntlet onto the floor. He speaks with a French accent.
A young man dashes forward to pick up the gauntlet first.

Dialogue.Line: My father is of ill-health, Sir Gilles.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hugh tries to slap Sir Gilles across the face with the gauntlet, but his arm is held firm.

Dialogue.Line: I beg your Majesty. Take my lands, my goods, my chattels, even the robes I stand in, but spare me my surviving son.
We shall see, my lord, if your fealty is as slender as your fortune. Your son shall meet our champion on the morrow. We shall retire and dream sweet dreams. We bid you goodnight.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The tents are set up outside Bodiam Castle in Sussex for the fight, and it has drawn a fair crowd.

King John takes his position on the dais amongst the nobles. Sir Gilles and Hugh are mounted on their chargers and don helmets before taking their lances and moving into position. The King gives the signal and the two knights charge down the lists at each other. The first pass is indecisive so they go again. Then the Tardis materialises, spooking the horses.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, friends, friends, calm yourselves. There's no cause for alarm.
You didn't set the coordinates for here by any chance?
Could this be a Black Guardian trap?
I don't think so, but something certainly isn't right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands Tegan a thick coat to put over her multi-coloured long- sleeved outfit.
The crowd gasp and take a step back as the Doctor comes out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: My liege, I have no need of aid from Lucifer.
Damn you cringing caitiffs. We tell you there's naught to fear. Do our demons come to visit us? Bid them attend us.
Makes a nice change for you not to take everything in your stride, I must say.
He even seems pleased to see us. A king welcoming demons.
Oh, Tegan. 1215? King John, of course.
The one who lost something in the Wash?
Well, you could put it like that. This particular shirt turned out to be the Crown Jewels, but that's next year. We're still three months away from Magna Carta.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two of the King's knights come to escort the Doctor, Turlough and Tegan to the King.

Dialogue.Line: Welcome, our demons. Name yourselves. Can this be Lilith?
Her name is Tegan, your Majesty. This is Turlough, and I am the Doctor. We are not demons.
You're too modest, Lord Doctor. Come, rejoice with us in a trial by combat. Come, make way for our demons. Let them be seated by us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ranulf and Isabella, and another man, give up their places. The knights replace their helms and charge down the lists again. Sir Gilles's lance catches Hugh square in the shield and knocks him to the ground. Whilst Hugh is still winded, Estram dismounts and raises his sword to kill Hugh.

Dialogue.Line: Your Majesty, if I may make so bold.
If this is trial by combat, your Majesty, there's clearly a victor and a vanquished. Must blood be shed?
We take your counsel, O demon. Spare him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Isabella goes to console her son. Sir Gilles listens from behind a pillar.
Hugh storms out.

Dialogue.Line: Heed him not, whoever you are. I am grateful. You are welcome at Fitzwilliam Castle.
Soon we shall sit at meat. Betimes you may wish to withdraw. Conduct my guests to their chamber.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A page leads the way.

Dialogue.Line: How can they live in such cold?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Turlough hangs back.

Dialogue.Line: He stopped to look at something. Look at the size of that bed!
Hmm. Another way of keeping warm.
What are we doing here, anyway?
We were invited for a meal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes a large skin from the bed.

Dialogue.Line: How long are you planning to stay?
Do you know, it's just sunk in. March the fourth, 1215.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Turlough is looking out of a small opening in the wall when he is touched on the shoulder by a sword point.

Dialogue.Line: The King takes the oath today.
To take the cross as a Crusader. But he did that in London.
Perhaps they got that bit wrong.
All I care about is getting back to the Tardis, where it's nice and warm. No wonder they forced him to sign Magna Carta. Bet there was something in it about underheated housing.
Forced into signing Magna Carta. He was as much for it as anyone.
Now look, Doctor, I know my history.
I would know who or what you are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Isabella is working on a tapestry, like a good noblewoman.

Dialogue.Line: He is proud, my Lord. He will never forgive you.
With all my heart. But he is your son. He is as proud as you.
Time heals. But at the present, my concern is for the King. Why is he so changed? And who are these beings he calls demons?
I must ask the Lady Isabella to accompany me.
Your lady is to be held in custody.
To be held in custody against your continued good behaviour toward our sovereign lord, the Kind.
The King is a guest in my house. He would not use me thus.
He would and does, my Lord.
Be not rash, my Lord. The King is resting. He sends word to not preserve pitchers. A new cider will be provided when he dines.
Be not provoked, my Lord. The King shall lack no comfort while within these walls.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Isabella is escorted out.
Turlough is held by two guards.

Dialogue.Line: I've nothing to hide. I'll tell you anything you want to know.
But you speak nothing but madness.
I've told you who I am and where I come from. What more do you want?
Are you the King's man like my father?
And what is this Doctor's purpose?
Well, perhaps I can loosen your tongue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hugh opens the smaller of two iron maidens.

Dialogue.Line: There really is no need for any of this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sound of footsteps.
Isabella enters.
Hugh tries to defend his mother, but Sir Gilles easily disarms him.

Dialogue.Line: Twice in one day. It is most embarrassing.
You'd best kill me now, for if you do not, I will most assuredly kill you.
Why is youth given to such extravagance?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sir Gilles throws Hugh across the room.

Dialogue.Line: It appears, my Lady, you will not be without companionship. Secure them! And then we will examine this demon's blue engine.
Are you saying King John was a good man?

Well, given the times he lives in, yes. But don't take my word for it. You'll be able to judge for yourself. Nobody forced Magna Carta from him. He could have crushed that rebellion as easily as that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor snaps his fingers. Ranulf enters, sword drawn.

Dialogue.Line: What have you demons made of the King? He is bewitched. First he takes my whole fortune, and now he has made my lady a hostage. How can he question my loyalty? There is none more loyal than I.
We are not demons and we've done no harm to the King, or to anyone. Nor do we intend any.
Yes, well. Please believe that we are friends. If you're in trouble, I would like to help if I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ranulf sheaths his sword and turns to his guards.

Dialogue.Line: Leave us, and fetch warm vestments.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards obey.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, yes, we seem to have mislaid Turlough. How long has the King been here?
Since yesterday. He is not himself. He's not as I know him.
In rude health. He rode from London yesterday, and then to a stag hunt to bring down the only kill.
Well, I can't say I care for him much myself. A French knight. Is he the only Frenchman with the King?
I know not. He has never favoured Frenchmen before this, even renegades from the King of France.
Could Sir Gilles be bringing some pressure, some influence on the King?
The King is influenced by none. The King I know is resolute and firm of purpose.
When does he return to London?
I know not, and no word from the city. My cousin was summoned there by the King a week since, and he's not returned. Why? And why no word concerning him?
Your cousin was summoned to London?
Aye, to take the Crusader's oath.
What say you, my Lord Doctor?
What if your guest was not the King?
I have known and served my sovereign lord for many years. No imposter could be so like.
Be vigilant, my Lord. I suspect things are not what they seem.
No, no, and I ask you to trust me, please.
You will join my household at meat.
Thank you, we would be delighted.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sir Gilles supervises the Tardis being carted into the castle. A large cloak has been provided for Tegan.

Dialogue.Line: Yes. Shouldn't we find out what's happened to Turlough?
A while longer, then we'll go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A pair of riders are greeted by Sir Gilles and his men.

Dialogue.Line: Geoffrey de Lacy, cousin to Ranulf Fitzwilliam. And your name?
Why then are you not with the King?
How can that be, since the King is in London?
Borne on eagle's wings? I left the King in the Tower this morning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The meal is already underway when the Doctor and Tegan enter.
The Doctor bows and Tegan curtseys.
The Doctor and Tegan take the seats that should be occupied by Isabella and Hugh, at Ranulf's left hand.
Turlough, Isabella and Hugh are all chained to the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Can you not call on Hell?
I could, but then so could you, with a better chance of success, I fancy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Four guards enter and carry away the smaller iron maiden.

Dialogue.Line: I do hope they've found a better use for it.
Not at all. You may disguise your features, but you can never disguise your intent.
You've always been my greatest stimulation, my dear Doctor, but now you inspire me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan throws a knife at the Master, but he catches it without even looking.

Dialogue.Line: Your first slip, my dear Doctor. Would you care to make a second?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master holds out both the TCE and the knife hilt to the Doctor. He snatches the TCE.

Dialogue.Line: And now a third. This is useless in your hands. You have moral scruples.
Come, what is this discourse? Consummate the victory.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master drops the knife.

Dialogue.Line: Come, kill me. Thwart my little game.
It is sufficient, your Majesty, that your Champion is disarmed.
Not for us. In sooth, this is but a puny demon that has no stomach for it. So be it. Let the Maiden embrace the vanquished.
Your Majesty, no! Have mercy! I beg you, no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is hustled into the Iron Maiden by a couple of guards.

Dialogue.Line: Sire, I must intercede. As victor, I beg you to be merciful.
We are not merciful, our demon.

Hold! We give you the choice, our demon. The Maiden shall embrace this snivelling wretch, or Sir Geoffrey. Choose, our demon. Come, the lady waits, impatient to lavish her warm favours. Come, our demon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gives Ranulf his sword back. The Master screams as the door of the Iron Maiden is closed and locked. Then it dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Behold, our demon. We too have tricks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chuckling, the Master settles himself at a control panel.

Dialogue.Line: He's using that imposter to bring the real King John into disrepute. And now he thinks he's trapped us into doing his dirty work for him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ranulf unshackles Geoffrey.

Dialogue.Line: Well, not if he is here since yesterday.
Or what. There's devil's work in this.
Our demon shall be our Champion. Accoutre him.
We must act, and without delay.
There is naught we can do. He has Isabella held hostage.
Then I must to London to warn the King.
Sir Geoffrey, surely you do not take your leave so soon? You are but arrived. Attend us. We would know how you think we can be in two places at the same time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master's Tardis materialises, still disguised as an Iron Maiden, and the Master steps out in his usual black costume.

Dialogue.Line: Nay, good sire, I am no demon. I come to help you. And to save the King from that demon that has bewitched him. Gaoler! Open, good fellow. The King is in danger.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The gaoler enters.

Dialogue.Line: I am the sworn enemy of that demon who calls himself the Doctor, who has come to defame the King and bring ill-repute to him.
Defame the King? Why should he?
To set the Barons of Britain against him, to provoke a great rebellion and topple him from the throne.
To serve the devilish Doctor's own purpose.
No, fellow, leave him. He serves the Doctor.
Don't listen to him, please. He is the evil one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor wears a thick robe and has a sword belt around his waist.

Dialogue.Line: Then let him attend us with his squire.
Your sword. Come, your sword. We grow tired.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gives King John his sword.
The King dubs the Doctor.
The Doctor takes back his sword.

Dialogue.Line: He says he comes as friend.
Your Majesty does me great honour. And my first action in this role shall be to arrest that man. Arrest Sir Geoffrey de Lacy.
A friend of thine, perhaps, not mine.
Unhand him. He is a man of honour. Lord Ranulf, is there a dungeon in this castle?
Sir Geoffrey, do you know it?
Then be so good as to lead me to it.
We like our new Champion. He's something of a jester.
I must insist you lead me to the dungeon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor draws his sword.

Dialogue.Line: You have no choice. Must I remind you that my sovereign lord holds the Lady Isabella hostage?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards start to accompany Geoffrey.

Dialogue.Line: No, my friends, attend the King. I have no need of assistance. Your Majesty. Sir Geoffrey.
We are tired. We shall retire and rest a while.
In the interest of security, where is the Master most likely to house his Tardis?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master, Isabella and Hugh hide outside as Geoffrey leads the Doctor and Tegan into the dungeon, then they leave. The gaoler brings the group into Turlough's cell.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, you won't believe this, but
You've seen another Tardis. Release him.
There is no Sir Gilles. He is the Master in disguise. Now, you could call him a demon. Sir Geoffrey, you are no longer a prisoner. Release him.
A friend, who wants to help. The Master has set up an imposter as King John of England.
To change the course of history.
What possible satisfaction can that give him?
He wants to rob the world of Magna Carta. Small time villainy by his standards, but nevertheless something I intend to stop if at all possible.
But why do you serve this imposter king?
To gain time, and access to this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns on the TCE and puts it either inside or behind the Maiden, I'm not sure which.

Dialogue.Line: Aye. Did we not take the Crusader's oath together but yesterday?
Then we must get you to London so you can warn him.
Oh, I can get you there much quicker than that.
Yes, but first we must bring it here, into the castle.
Look, let's all get out of here while we've still got the chance.
No, we must bring the imposter with us.
To expose the Master's plan. Now, come along. (to gaoler) If you so much as touch this, something very nasty will happen to you.
You're never leaving the compressor here for the Master.
As a matter of fact, I am.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Fitzwilliam family are reunited.

Dialogue.Line: Name what you will, Lord Master. It shall be yours.
I ask no reward. I wish merely to rid the King of his demons. That's why I'm here.
How long has the King been thus afflicted?
Who can tell? Perhaps he's always been accursed.
Have we any power against this sorcery?
Then this Doctor demon must be captured and put to the fire.
If then, my lord, you will put your knights and men-at-arms at my command.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Tegan, Turlough and Geoffrey discover the Tardis has already been removed.

Dialogue.Line: The tracks lead directly to the castle.
I will alone to London, if someone will help with a horse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ranulf leads in his fighting men.

Dialogue.Line: This is the Lord Master, come to rid the King of his demons. Obey him in all things.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hugh runs in.

Dialogue.Line: Find these demons and bring them hither.
And the engine. Without it, they're helpless.
What of the King? Is he guarded?
I've seen to this. I'll oversee the search and then attend the King.
But he couldn't have got the Tardis in here. None of the outer doors is big enough.
Well, not for Sir Gilles. All the Master has to do is set coordinates.
The same place he keeps the King.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They meet a group of men-at-arms.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, I wonder if you'd be so good as to show me to the King's chamber. I must insist. I am the King's Champion.
No longer, Sir Demon. Take them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Turlough slaps the horse's rump, and Sir Geoffrey trots across the drawbridge on his white charger.
The Master watches from an upper 'window' as a crossbowman takes aim and shoots the rider in the back.
Turlough is apprehended.

Dialogue.Line: So I see. Where was it?
Where you left it, with the King. Did you think to kidnap him? Your plan is foiled. Where is Geoffrey?
Safely on his way to London.
He should be there in a few hours.
The coordinates will be set. Get into the Tardis.
No, I believe he may be in the Tardis. Blue engine.
No, I must open it. Other demons may try to harm you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises and everyone crowds round where it had been, allowing the Doctor to remove his cloak and slip away, watched only by the Master in the minstrel's gallery.

Dialogue.Line: The demon has vanished! Find Sir Geoffrey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something starts beeping.
The Doctor discards the last piece of his mediaeval robes and puts his jacket back on. Then he hears a lute playing.

Dialogue.Line: (singing) We sing in praise of total war against the Saracen we abhor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: (singing) To free the tomb of Christ our Lord

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the singer is actually a silver android.

Dialogue.Line: We'll put the known world to the sword. Welcome, my demon.
Your Majesty seems in need of a doctor.
Alas, modesty forbids such a claim. Kamelion is a tool of an earlier invader of Xeriphas, and instrumental in my escape from that benighted planet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kamelion transforms itself from metal to apparent flesh and blood including clothes.

Dialogue.Line: A weapon used by the invaders of Xeriphas. A decoy, capable of infinite form or personality.
Well said, my demon. We are a complex mass of artificial neurons.
Nothing more than simple concentration and psychokinetics. Look again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: King John transforms into the Doctor.
Kamelion becomes the Master.

Dialogue.Line: You flatter me. I prefer bad King John.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The stricken Geoffrey is laid out on furs, on a table.

Dialogue.Line: Speak, cousin. Who has done this?
So Kamelion here is bad King John.
Aided and abetted by you, his demon, and your blue engine.
It's cunning of you to confirm the superstitions put about by the monks.
Irresistible. Your arrival here was most timely.
The King turns the Barons solidly against him, he is killed in battle or deposed, possibly in favour of King Phillip of France. He cannot therefore offer Magna Carta. What do you think of it so far?
Thus the foundations of parliamentary democracy will never be laid.
You cannot be allowed to alter the course of history, even indirectly.
How do you propose to stop me?
I shall have to give it some thought.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hugh brings in Turlough.

Dialogue.Line: Vile villain! He has slain Sir Geoffrey.
You will die in torment, catiff.
You're always threatening me, and without the slightest justification.
I was trying to help him.
To a horse, to get to London.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Geoffrey dies.

Dialogue.Line: Seek the Doctor? Where, in hell?
He will be with the King. Bring the rogue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The console is still beeping.

Dialogue.Line: You would do well, my dear Doctor, to ponder that you played directly into my hand.
He has a mind of his own?

You will know that the King and his dead brothers are believed to be the devil's work. Your interference here with your dreary Tardis has only confirmed this. You are, dare I say so, discredited demons, and as such you make a unique contribution to altering the course of history. Hoist on your own petard.
And where will you take your toy next?
Does it matter? You'll not be there to greet me.
I may not need to. You forget, Kamelion does have a mind of his own.
Yes, but for how much longer?
For as long as I command it. Kamelion will not turn on me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tries to change Kamelion, and fails. The Master laughs.

Dialogue.Line: You're getting old, Doctor. Your will is weak. It's time you regenerated.
You're mistaken. With Kamelion's unique ability at my command, it's only a matter of time before I undermine the key civilisations of the universe. Chaos will reign, and I shall be its emperor.
Earth is a primitive planet. You won't succeed so easily elsewhere.
Where I cannot win by stealth, I shall destroy. That way I cannot fail to win.
Unfortunately, you will not be alive to find out. Which reminds me. My compressor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a hammering at the door.
Kamelion transforms.

Dialogue.Line: Sire, they have slain my kinsman.
Such perfidy must not go unpunished. We would have boiling oil. See to it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ranulf and Hugh leave. Turlough is still in the arms of two men-at-arms.

Dialogue.Line: Yes. Yes, I'm not a demon for nothing.
Very well, my dear Doctor. Your will against mine? So be it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two Time Lords both concentrate on Kamelion, who goes blurry. Meanwhile, Tegan finally hits the Tardis console in just the right place. Ranulf and Hugh return.

Dialogue.Line: The King! What ails the King?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ranulf is distracted by the Tardis materialising behind him. Kamelion changes from King John to Tegan and the Doctor drags her away into the Tardis. Turlough grabs a sword.

Dialogue.Line: I've had quite enough of you, whoever you are, so don't try me too far.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Turlough backs into the Tardis, the door slams shut and it dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Mediaeval misfits! Don't think you've won yet, Doctor.
I don't believe it. Can you see it too?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kamelion changes into its android form.

Dialogue.Line: Who is it, if you please.
Well, Tegan, it's a long story which appears to begin on Xeriphas.
And who knows when it will end.
Oh, it will end with the Master.
You're not going to leave the Master here to carry out his plan?

Well, he's without Kamelion now, and he won't be on Earth for much longer. I took the opportunity of leaving his compressor activated. Won't do his dimension circuits much good. He could end up anywhere except where he wants to go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Down in the castle dungeon, the Master gets into his Iron Maiden Tardis and dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: What are we going to do with him?
Well, he can't stay on board.
And very cooperative. I would make an excellent colleague.
Unexpected as it may be, I do have a mind of my own.
And a very fine mind it is too.
I would be honoured if you will allow me to stay.
I apologise for Tegan's bad manners.
He's a machine, Doctor, just a machine. How can we be certain he still isn't under the control of the Master?
I'm very grateful, Doctor. Where will I be quartered?
You can have my room, for all I care.
Your own time. I assume that's where you'd prefer to be.
We were on our way to my planet, actually.
I don't want to go home.
Of course you do. You don't have to pretend. It's a shame, of course. There were many wonders I wanted to show you.
But you wish to return home.
No. Show me the Eye of Orion, please.
All right. You won't regret it, I promise you.
Well, aren't you going to reset the coordinates?
